awd_titl_txt: RoL: EAGER: DESYN-C3: Mimicking Mitochondria: Developing Synthetic Pathways to Power Pseudo-Cell Functions using Diverse Fuel Resources
awd_abstract_narration:
A few key molecules act as central electron and energy carriers inside cells. Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH) transfers electrons and adenosine triphosphate (ATP) supplies energy. The most common method to produce ATP requires a pH gradient to be established across a membrane. The resulting flow of protons through an embedded protein regenerates ATP.  This project will test the hypothesis that alternative pathways could be developed that can regenerate ATP from NADH oxidation without the need for a membrane, proton gradient, or embedded enzyme. This will require combining  native and engineered enzymes to create novel cyclic pathways.  These pathways will help uncover design rules required to replicate a central biological process. This technology will be critical to the development of synthetic cells. In addition, the project will involve mentoring of students and expanding existing outreach activities in the local community.

This project will design, build and test novel synthetic metabolic pathways that could regenerate ATP using energy obtained from fuel oxidation. Fuel oxidation pathways can generate reducing equivalents in the form of NADH.  However other critical operations, especially those involving motion, are powered by the hydrolysis of ATP.  Oxidative phosphorylation in mitochondria supplies the majority of cellular ATP from NADH oxidation and this requires the establishment of a proton gradient.  Although this supplies flexibility for cellular energy processing, replicating this system presents a difficult engineering challenge.  We hypothesize that oxidative phosphorylation could be replaced with novel pathways composed of kinase enzymes.  These pathways will use fuel oxidation reactions to drive NADH regeneration and NAD(H) phosphorylation will drive ATP regeneration.  As a proof-of-concept, an ATP-dependent reaction (firefly luciferase) powered by methanol oxidation in simple liposomes will be demonstrated.  This will represent a novel energy transduction alternative to mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation.  This pathway could be easily adopted to use a wide range of potential fuels, supporting many potential future synthetic cell and biology applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Energy transduction in cells is accomplished via the use of high energy cofactor molecules including NAD(P)(H) and ATP.  NAD(P)(H) is the predominant cofactor used for redox reactions, including fuel oxidation.  ATP is the main energy molecule used for processes involving actuation and motion.  The majority of ATP in cells is regenerated using the oxidation of NAD(H) which is produced via the TCA cycle.  The oxidation of NADH is used to create a proton gradient across a cellular membrane.  This gradient is exploited to drive ATP synthase enzymes which rotate and regenerate ATP from ADP.           

Several emerging applications will benefit from new membrane-less ATP regeneration cascades such as cell free proteins synthesis (CFPS) and the design and engineering of synthetic or pseudo cells.  Current membrane-less methods rely on expensive phosphate donor molecules, which are not common fuel sources in most environments. We have proposed, developed, and demonstrated a novel membrane-less ATP regeneration pathway that is energetically driven by NADH oxidation. Because NADH is the predominant cofactor used in metabolic fuel oxidation, many enzymes can be chosen to produce NADH. Therefore, ATP can be regeneration by an enzyme cascade that is driven by fuel oxidation.

The ATP generating cascade consists of 4 enzymes that utilize NAD(P)(H): a formate dehydrogenase from C. boidinii (FDH), a polyphosphate NADK from B. subtilis (PPNK), a water-forming NADPH oxidase from L. brevis (TPNOX), and, the center of the enzyme cascade, ATP-NAD+ NAD kinase (NADK) from C. livia (pigeon).  After some optimization, we were able to demonstrate a continuous ATP regeneration rate of 0.30 μM ATP/(μM NADK*h) over 4 hours using the cascade.  We implemented the cascade in a CFPS platform and showed the ATP regeneration could support high levels of expression of superfolder Green Fluorescent Protein (sfGFP) and the Horseradish Peroxidase (HRP) enzyme.

The impact of this work stems from the demonstration of a new synthetic cascade for the regeneration of a critical cofactor molecule, ATP, via a pathway not known to be utilized in nature.   This may serve as a new capability for the development of future biotechnology applications.  In addition, a graduate student was funded on this project, and she is considering an academic career upon graduation.  This work will lead to two peer-reviewed publications, which are in preparation.
